div.sent: Bangladesh is an agro-based country.
Most people of this country live in village and agriculture is the main source of their livelihood.
But with the expansion of urban areas the role of industry and commerce has gradually become more significant in our economy.
In a developed country, agriculture, industry, trade and commerce no sector of these is less important than others.
To develop our country we have to make national economy strong and dynamic from all sides.
There is no alternative to this in the present competitive world.
For this, we have to develop all sectors including agriculture, industry, trade and commerce.
Any work, service or transaction that has economic value is called economic activity.
The economic activities of a country can be divided into two types formal and informal.
For example, work in one's own land and in shops or business institutions, house-hold works, and the works of hawkers and day labourers, etc.
In underdeveloped or developing countries maximum economic activities are run through the informal sectors.
As it has been happening from the ancient period, these activities are also called traditional sector of economy.
The informal economic activities in Bangladesh, like in any other developing countries, play the main role in the economy of Bangladesh.
In a village, a farmer and his family members work in the field from morning to evening in a village.
They do not get or take any wage for working in their own field.
However, their labour or industry not only benefits their family but also the society and the country.
The larger portion of the country's food demand is met by their production.
Thus our farmers are contributing significantly to our national economy.
The work of blacksmiths and potters and such, cottage industry in villages and other small business enterprises or micro-business belong to this informal economic sector.
These works are playing a vital role in keeping our economy dynamic.
From the point of national economy, too, this sector is playing an important role.
People of all classes high, middle or lower, and the poor live in the urban areas of Bangladesh.
Their activities are considered as informal economic activities.
Not only this, they also largely contribute to keeping our national economy dynamic.
In this way, from the beginning, the economy of Bangladesh has been dependent much on informal economy.
Although Bangladesh is an agricultural country, from the British reign some factories and industries were flourishing.
Among them jute, cotton and textile industries were the main ones.
The Adamjee Jute Mills, the largest jute mill in the world was established at Narayanganj in the then East Pakistan.
East Pakistan was subject to gross discrimination and deprivation in establishing factories and industries by the Pakistani rulers.
Recently, Bangladesh has achieved a great success in garment and pharmaceutical industry.
These industries need huge capital, skilled workers and craftsmen, engineers, expert and experienced managers.
The production capacity of these industries is also very high.
After meeting the local demand, a portion of production is exported to foreign countries.
The importance of these large industries is very high in our national economy.
These industries work as the economic backbone of our country.
Industry having capital of more than 1.5 crore is called medium industry.
For example, light engineering, silk, ceramic and cold storage, etc.
These industries play an important role in our national economy by creating employment and meeting the local demand.
Those industries whose capital is less than 1.5 crore is called small industry.
Handloom, earthen wares, bamboo, cane and wood works, Sari or sweet packets, agorbati are some examples of cottage industries.
Our life is incapacitated not only just without food, cloth and medicine, today we cannot imagine our life without fuel, electricity and house building materials.
And we get all these from different kinds of industries.
A large number of people earn their livelihood, next to agriculture, from these industries.
In absence of these industries the rate of unemployment would have increased.
In recent times, the expansion of garments industry has made opportunities for millions of people, especially for the women.
It has also contributed to social advancement.
Opportunities for employment in industries have made the people interested in education and technology.
The use of modern technology is thus helping us become the citizens of the world.
Bangladesh is a potential country in the field of industry.
It has vast human resources.
Here both skilled and unskilled laborers are available at a comparatively low wage.
As a result foreign investors are interested in investing and establishing industries in this country.
Different foreign companies have established garment industries individually and jointly with the people of this country.
The garments products of this country are well received in the international market.
The foreigners are showing their interest to invest not only in garments sectors but also in other industries.
Government has established several export processing zones to attract foreign investors.
As a result, a great possibility is appearing for the establishment of different industries in future.
Now-a-days many of the Bangladeshis who work abroad are showing interest to establish industries in this country.
Thus the possibilities of Bangladesh being an industrially developed middle income country is being gradually brightened.
Generally, a country itself cannot produce all the things of its demand.
It has to import some commodities from other countries to meet the demand.
A country exports a portion of produced commodities to foreign countries after meeting the internal demand.
A country generally exports goods which it produces in huge amount.
The import and export of various commodities or goods among different countries is called international trade.
International trade has an important role in the economy of any country.
In the modern world the scope of international trade has much increased.
No country can think of producing all commodities of its demand.
Rather, considering the economy of a country, the commodities or goods which are easy and profitable to export and import are exported and imported.
This trade is run under a certain plan and policy.
Under mutual contract, import and export or international trade activities are operated among different countries.
In the international trade, the country which exports more than imports is called a developed country.
This trade is run by both the government and non- government sectors.
This amount is less than the previous two years.
That is to say, the expenditure of Bangladesh in import sector is decreasing.
Once upon a time jute was the main export commodity of Bangladesh.
Our country earned a lot of foreign currencies by exporting jute, jute goods like sack, carpet, etc.
But for some years demand of jute and jute goods has decreased in the world market.
Bangladesh exports not only jute and jute goods but also tea, hides and skins, readymade garments, prawn, handicraft, vegetables and different food items.
The U.S.A is the largest buyer of Bangladeshi commodities including garments.
Germany, UK and France also import commodities from Bangladesh.
Bangladesh imports mainly those commodities from foreign courtiers, which are necessary to meet the demand of food and other demands.
In case of failure to import those commodities in time, the country normally would face extreme want and price hike of those commodities.
As a result, social and political unrest would happen in the country.
No country in the world can produce all the commodities of its demand.
It imports commodities with reasonable price under trade policy.
Bangladesh is not different from others.
Bangladesh exports some commodities regularly.
Bangladesh earns significant foreign exchange from it.
It helps not only to keep the economy dynamic, but also creates opportunities for employment and expansion of industry.
As a nation we can be self- reliant by reducing import and increasing export.
By ensuring large involvement of the people with production, we can be financially self- reliant.
In order to make Bangladesh a middle income and industrially potential country, we have to put more emphasis on international trade, especially on export.
